statement:
Let $A$ be a square complex matrix. Around every element $a_{ii}$ on the
diagonal of the matrix, we draw a circle with radius the sum of the
norms of the other elements on the same row $\sum_{j\neq i}|a_{ij}|$.
Such circles are called *Gershgorin discs*.

Theorem: Every eigenvalue of A lies in one of these Gershgorin discs.

Proof: Let $\lambda$ be an eigenvalue of $A$ and $x$ its corresponding
eigenvector. Choose $i$ such that $|x_i|={\max}_j |x_j|$. Since $x$
can’t be $0$, $|x_i|>0$. Now $Ax=\lambda x$, or looking at the $i$-th
component $$(\lambda - a_{ii})x_i = \sum_{j\neq i} a_{ij}x_j.$$ Taking
the norm on both sides gives
$$|\lambda - a_{ii}|=|\sum_{j\neq i} \frac{a_{ij}x_j}{x_i}|\leq \sum_{j\neq i}|a_{ij}|.$$
